comment.author: 8944614@N02
comment._content: I'm unfamiliar with the Spanish early modern epigraphics and don't know Spanish, so, unfortunately, can not read this inscription in its entirety. From a point of view of somebody who studied a bit of the ancient Greek and Latin inscriptions, I must say that this one is very interesting, among other things, in how it mimics a written-on-paper text; perhaps, it was actually written first on a piece of paper and then faithfully copied on that rock.

comment.author: 23170389@N03
comment._content: www.flickr.com/photos/openthreads/3320945926/ "Aqui estubo el Gen[era]l D[o]n D[ieg]o de varg[a]s, q[uie]n Conquisto a n[uest]ra S[ant]a Fe Y a la R[ea]l Corona todo el Neubo Mexico a su costa. Ano de 1692" General Don Diego de Vargas, who conquered for our Holy Faith and for the Royal Crown, all of New Mexico, at his own expense, was here, in the year 1692.

comment.author: 87914514@N00
comment._content:
I like the 'at his own expense' bit.

It's like a giant, rocky I.O.U. for his little place in heaven.
'See? I conquered all of Mexico for the Holy Faith at my own expense! Surely that's got to get me past those pearly gates.'
